messageBody:
--- J. B. Rainsbergerwrote:
> Do I understand correctly?

Not completely, but that is just because you have to deal with the
information I give to you :-). I think that your questions are
justified given the available info.

> You appear to be using the TestCase object to create test cases
that
> will be executed by something else. This is not what JUnit was
designed
> for, so I am confused why you are doing things this way.

The testcases are still able to run in the JUnit testrunner. I
didn't change anything of that. It just plugs in new assertStuff()
methods necessary for our testcases, like the assertion that some
audit-log record has been written, or that some errorcode has been
set after three times a time-out at a menu. But that's getting too
deep. (The testcases are run using ant, though).

> Why are you writing XML tags at all?

The asserts, dial commands, and other checks, and some of the
functional loggings are written to one single logfile for the
testcases to be debugged. So the xml-file will look after
transformation with a stylesheet to something like this:

dial 1234567890
assert that the status connected has been reached within 5
seconds
phone has remote ringing
phone has connected
assert that voicesegment WELKOM.wav is played within 5 seconds
audit record 21004 has been written
config parameter OPENINGHOURS_OPEN is 09:00
config parameter OPENINGHOURS_CLOSE is 21:00
voicesegment WELKOM.wav is played
waiting for OTHERCHOICES.wav to be played within 1 seconds
voicesegment MAINMENU.wav is played
voicesegment CHOICE1.wav is played
failed test 'menu choice 1': OTHERCHOICES.wav was not played
within 1 seconds, last voicesegment played is CHOICE1.wav

> Reading more, you appear to be doing logging in the test case. Why
are
> you not doing this logging in something like a test runner?

The logging is done in the asserts, so that we can track which tests
have succeeded, and how the flow of the program has passed. This way
we don't have to have the source of the testcase directly available
when we are looking at the test reports. Because my project manager
(!) is also defining and debugging the tests he has written (he
sometimes makes mistakes, just as the hardcore programmers do), the
log has to be readable for mere mortals. Hence the XML -> html.

Furthermore, the environment is asynchronous in nature: the test
application and the IVR application run in different threads,
possibly in different JVM's, or even machines. Therefore all the
assert's have a time-out. Therefore the logging is essential for
seeing the timing aspects: sometimes the time-out is set too small
for the application to perform it's actions. Then it is very handy
to have the log displaying when the time-out occurred and where the
application was.

Hope this eleviates some of your concerns :-)

With regards,

Martijn Dashorst
